title.children: Lidia Thorpe says No vote win would be a 'victory' for Blak Sovereign Movement

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Independent senator and progressive No figurehead Lidia Thorpe said a No result in Saturday's Voice referendum would be the start of a "healing journey" for the country. "I see that as a victory for the Blak sovereign movement that have resisted colonisation for 200 years," she said. "This would be a beginning of a real healing journey and a truth-telling journey that this country must take before anybody makes any decisions on us, without us. "I think there’s lots to look forward to." Last Thursday, Senator Thorpe made allegations that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the AFP were not doing enough to protect her from far-right extremism after being the target of an offensive video. Senator Thorpe told RN's Patricia Karvelas that she believes the referendum "gave platform for the racists". "The racism we've seen, the far-right Nazis coming out. All the bad behaviour from a lot of sections of our country, is part of an illness in this country that needs to be healed," she said. "This is the government’s fault, this is Anthony Albanese’s fault we're seeing a rise in racism, we're seeing families split, we've seen communities divided." "We should never have gone to this referendum in the first place." Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No result would be a 'victory' for Blak sovereign movement, says Lidia Thorpe

featuredLink.title: How will Saturday's outcome impact reconciliation? - ABC listen

children.content: Independent senator and progressive No figurehead
Lidia Thorpe
said a No result in Saturday's Voice referendum would be the start of a "healing journey" for the country.
"I see that as a victory for the Blak sovereign movement that have resisted colonisation for 200 years," she said.
"This would be a beginning of a real healing journey and a truth-telling journey that this country must take before anybody makes any decisions on us, without us.
"I think there’s lots to look forward to."
Last Thursday, Senator Thorpe made allegations
that
Prime Minister
Anthony Albanese
and the AFP were not doing enough to protect her from far-right extremism after being the target of an offensive video.
Senator Thorpe told RN's
Patricia Karvelas
that she believes the referendum "gave platform for the racists".
"The racism we've seen, the far-right Nazis coming out. All the bad behaviour from a lot of sections of our country, is part of an illness in this country that needs to be healed," she said.
"This is the government’s fault, this is Anthony Albanese’s fault we're seeing a rise in racism, we're seeing families split, we've seen communities divided."
"We should never have gone to this referendum in the first place."
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For months, the No campaign has cited fears of legal risks arising from the wording of the proposed amendment to the constitution. Former High Court Judge Kenneth Hayne told RN's Patricia Karvelas this morning that the "overwhelming weight" among constitutional lawyers and scholars was that the wording was "wholly sound". He said a person or group taking an issue to court should not be feared. "It is simply a by-product of the fact that we live in a rule of law society," Mr Hayne said. "People can go to court to test issues. "The fact that someone wants to bring a challenge does not mean that the challenge will succeed." Listen to the full audio below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Voice wording legally 'wholly sound' says former High Court judge

featuredLink.title: Voice wording legally 'wholly sound' says former High Court judge - ABC listen

children.content: For months, the No campaign has cited fears of legal risks arising from the wording of the proposed amendment to the constitution.
Former High Court Judge Kenneth Hayne
told
RN's Patricia Karvelas
this morning that the "overwhelming weight" among constitutional lawyers and scholars was that the wording was "wholly sound".
He said a person or group taking an issue to court should not be feared.
"It is simply a by-product of the fact that we live in a rule of law society," Mr Hayne said.
"People can go to court to test issues.
"The fact that someone wants to bring a challenge does not mean that the challenge will succeed."
Listen to the full audio below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yes. All Australian citizens aged 18 and over must vote in the referendum. If you're on the electoral roll and do not vote, you will need to provide a valid reason explaining why If you don't you may face a $20 fine, courtesy of the AEC. Find out more below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is it compulsory to vote in the Voice referendum?

featuredLink.title: Is it compulsory to vote in the Voice referendum? Here's what you should know

children.content: Yes.
All Australian citizens aged 18 and over must vote in the referendum.
If you're on the electoral roll and do not vote, you will need to provide a valid reason explaining why
If you don't
you may face a $20 fine
, courtesy of the AEC.
Find out more below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Faced with evacuation sirens and uncertainty, Yuliya Mik is among the dual Israeli-Australian citizens facing the difficult decision of whether to stay in Tel Aviv, or mobilise with her community. She told The World Today bombs are falling in her city, even though she's far from the southern and northern borders, creating a lot of anxiety and uncertainty. It also means, along with her husband and six-month-old baby, they need to be prepared to run to safety at any moment. "For me that means, as soon as I hear a bomb siren, I grab my baby and my husband grabs our dog and we have to just run for cover, we have a minute and a half to get to the nearest shelter, which for us is not in our apartment, it's next door in the neighbouring building and it's just we're a couple of times a day at the moment, literally running for our lives," she said. "We just have to be on alert, 24 hours a day, we have to make sure that we go to bed clothed and with our phones within reach because if we have to get up and run in the middle of the night then we have no choice, we're just on hyper alert all the time." The federal government has announced repatriation fights for Australians in Israel, but Ms Mik isn't sure she will yet join them. While her family in Melbourne are begging her to leave, she is aware everyone is suffering and doesn't want to "abandon ship."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I hear a bomb siren, I grab my baby': Israeli-Australian citizen faces decision of whether to stay or leave Tel Aviv

children.content: Faced with evacuation sirens and uncertainty, Yuliya Mik is among the dual Israeli-Australian citizens facing the difficult decision of whether to stay in Tel Aviv, or
mobilise with her community.
She told The World Today bombs are falling in her city, even though she's far from the southern and northern borders, creating a lot of anxiety and uncertainty.
It also means, along with her husband and six-month-old baby, they need to be prepared to run to safety at any moment.

"For me that means, as soon as I hear a bomb siren, I grab my baby and my husband grabs our dog and we have to just run for cover, we have a minute and a half to get to the nearest shelter, which for us is not in our apartment, it's next door in the neighbouring building and it's just we're a couple of times a day at the moment, literally running for our lives," she said.

"We just have to be on alert, 24 hours a day, we have to make sure that we go to bed clothed and with our phones within reach because if we have to get up and run in the middle of the night then we have no choice, we're just on hyper alert all the time."
The federal government has
announced repatriation fights for Australians in Israel,
but
Ms Mik isn't sure she will yet join them.
While her family in Melbourne are begging her to leave, she is aware everyone is suffering and doesn't want to "abandon ship."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Monash University lecturer and analyst on Israel and Middle Eastern Affairs Ran Porat has spoken with ABC News about how the unity government in Israel will work. "The practicalities of this government will be mostly around the cabinet and the additional minister that will join the government," Dr Porat says. "There is going to be five new ministers with no official titles and others will stand at the side as onlookers. "The thing is the government will be stuck with a lot of veteran politicians and veterinary IDF, Israeli army commanders, including two former chief of staff themselves. "The idea is to have people with experience in operational aspects of war with consideration or considering the implications of specific rules and also discussing what is on everybody's mind the day after, what will happen, what is the exit strategy of this war in response to Hamas's horrendous attack on Israel." He says it is a "positive step in the eyes of the Israeli public". Dr Porat says despite the unity government forming, the criticisms of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government will not go away. "It is put on ice but it does not go away," he says. "[Mr] Netanyahu did make it clear he will not put anything controversial now, which is expected, but people in Israel have not forgotten [the judicial overhaul]." " Many on the camp that objected to the judicial overhaul see [Mr] Netanyahu possibly with some truth behind him that he is responsible for this global failure. " "The divisions in Israel is understood [to be] around the Middle East as a sign of weakness. " It is something that the enemies of Israel saw fit as a sort of opportunity to attack Israel because they saw Israel as weak." Dr Porat says all the divisions have been put aside and the Israeli public is completely behind the war effort.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ran Porat explains how Israel's unity government will work

"The idea is to have people with experience in operational aspects of war with consideration or considering the implications of specific rules and also discussing what is on everybody's mind the day after, what will happen, what is the exit strategy of this war in response to Hamas's horrendous attack on Israel."
He says it is a "positive step in the eyes of the Israeli public".

in Israel is understood [to be] around the
Middle East as a sign of weakness. "
It is something that the enemies of Israel saw fit as a sort of opportunity to attack Israel because they saw Israel as weak."
Dr Porat says all the divisions have been put aside and the Israeli public is completely behind the war effort.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By political reporter Jake Evans Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong has confirmed a third repatriation flight for citizens in Israel is being arranged. The flight will leave early next week with further details to be released by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade within the next 24 hours. Senator Wong says the department is coordinating the flight, and anyone seeking to leave should register their interest through Smart Traveller. She said the government was considering whether further flights were needed. "I did last night agree to a third flight," she said. "My anticipation is that demand will require at least a further flight. We will look at whether any further assisted departures are required."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong confirms third repatriation flight for Australians in Israel

children.content: Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong.
(ABC News: Adam Kennedy)
By political reporter Jake Evans
Foreign Affairs Minister
Penny Wong
has confirmed a third repatriation flight for citizens in Israel is being arranged.
The flight will leave early next week with further details to be released by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade within the next 24 hours.
Senator Wong says the department is coordinating the flight, and anyone seeking to leave should register their interest through
Smart Traveller
She said the government was considering whether further flights were needed.
"I did last night agree to a third flight," she said.
"My anticipation is that demand will require at least a further flight. We will look at whether any further assisted departures are required."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of Japan's oldest and largest firms will end its 74-year stock market history by the end of this year. It will hold an extraordinary shareholder's meeting next month to approve the consolidation of its shares. Toshiba will be delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange on December 20. Last month the Japanese conglomerate announced the success of a 2 trillion yen ($US13.4 billion) tender offer from private equity firm Japan Industrial Partners. JIP purchased 78.65 per cent of Toshiba's shares. Toshiba can be dated back to 1875 when it began as a maker of telegraph equipment. Now it has divisions ranging from home electronics to nuclear power stations. It started trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in May 1949 when it reopened after World War II. In 1985 Toshiba launched what it called 'the first mass-market laptop computer'. But the attention it's gained hasn't always been positive. In 2015 Toshiba admitted to overstating its profits over six years. It sold its memory chip business in 2018 to avoid bankruptcy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Japanese tech firm Toshiba to delist and go private

children.content: One of Japan's oldest and largest firms will
end its 74-year stock market history
by the end of this year.
It will hold an extraordinary shareholder's meeting next month to approve the consolidation of its shares.
Toshiba will be delisted from the Tokyo Stock Exchange on December 20.
Last month the Japanese conglomerate announced the success of a 2 trillion yen ($US13.4 billion) tender offer from private equity firm
Japan Industrial Partners
JIP purchased 78.65 per cent of Toshiba's shares.
Toshiba can be
dated back to 1875
when it began as a maker of telegraph equipment.
Now it has divisions ranging from home electronics to nuclear power stations.
It
started trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in May 1949
when it reopened after World War II.
In 1985 Toshiba launched what it called 'the first mass-market laptop computer'.
But the attention it's gained hasn't always been positive.
In 2015 Toshiba admitted to overstating its profits over six years.
It sold its memory chip business in 2018 to avoid bankruptcy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Senate hearing as just returning from lunch where before that former CEO of PwC, Luke Sayers, said he was sorry about the tax leak sandal and that he was not aware of unethical behaviour at the time. It was the first time Mr Sayers has answered questions on the saga. My colleague Daniel Ziffer filed this update on his appearance. We have been waiting for a really long time to hear from the man who was a CEO are the key period tween 2012 and 2020 when tax information was taken from a confidential Treasury briefing and plans for how the then Treasurer Joe Hockey were taken, reverse engineered and then a scheme to get around those plans was sold to multinational tax companies around the world. PwC made millions of dollars from doing this, involving the global arms to sell these plans and deny Australian taxpayers getting more tax. It came to light earlier this year and we been waiting to hear from him and we finally did today. He is very sorry. "Of course I feel terrible. I am sure every PwC person feels terrible. I feel… I feel accountable. It is a terrible, terrible situation. The bottom line is that there was a number of bad actor tax partners that behaviorally made the wrong choices," Mr Sayers told the hearing. Inquiries are ongoing - there is an AFP potential criminal inquiry, and ASIC and other bodies are looking at PwC consulting firms as well. The new CEO of the company, Kevin Burrowes, who has been brought in from overseas to try to clean up the mess, made it very clear that it was about multiple failures of leadership. The vast majority occurred during the time that Mr Sayers was a CEO. More to come on this long-running saga, which raises a lot of questions about government dealings with these consulting firms.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former PwC CEO, Luke Sayers, 'not aware of unethical behaviour'

children.content: The Senate hearing as just returning from lunch where before that former CEO of PwC, Luke Sayers, said he was sorry about the tax leak sandal and that he was not aware of unethical behaviour at the time.
It was the first time Mr Sayers has answered questions on the saga.
My colleague
Daniel Ziffer
filed this update on his appearance.

We have been waiting for a really long time to hear from the man who was a CEO are the key period tween 2012 and 2020 when tax information was taken from a confidential Treasury briefing and plans for how the then Treasurer Joe Hockey were taken, reverse engineered and then a scheme to get around those plans was sold to multinational tax companies around the world.
PwC made millions of dollars from doing this, involving the global arms to sell these plans and deny Australian taxpayers getting more tax.
It came to light earlier this year and we been waiting to hear from him and we finally did today. He is very sorry.

"Of course I feel terrible. I am sure every PwC person feels terrible. I feel… I feel accountable. It is a terrible, terrible situation. The bottom line is that there was a number of bad actor tax partners that behaviorally made the wrong choices," Mr Sayers told the hearing.
Inquiries are ongoing - there is an AFP potential criminal inquiry, and ASIC and other bodies are looking at PwC consulting firms as well.
The new CEO of the company,
Kevin Burrowes,
who has been brought in from overseas to try to clean up the mess, made it very clear that it was about multiple failures of leadership.
The vast majority occurred during the time that Mr Sayers was a CEO.
More to come on this long-running saga, which raises a lot of questions about government dealings with these consulting firms.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We are continuing our look ahead to the draft class of 2023 with a glance at another Tasmanian midfielder destined for the top 10. Ryley Sanders is a big-bodied workhorse in midfield who dominated his under-18 year with his combination of inside grunt and outside skill. The Larke Medallist teamed up with Colby McKercher to lead the Allies to victory in the state champs and enjoyed a fantastic season with the Sandringham Dragons. He proved a commanding presence in midfield, a real leader of both sides, and quickly became a favourite among draft watchers. It's a stretch to say he plays like him, but with the blonde hair and pulled-up socks he does genuinely look like Jason Horne-Francis when he plays. He doesn't have the explosive athleticism of Horne-Francis, but he does move a bit like him and makes up for that lack of top-level pace with a fantastic work ethic. He's a little more one-paced than someone like McKercher, but he's quick enough. And when he's frame fills out further he could well be a force for any AFL midfield. North Melbourne are big fans and tried to get the AFL to let them have priority access to him via their NGA, but Sanders is available to all and sundry on the open market.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Ryley Sanders

children.content: We are continuing our look ahead to the draft class of 2023 with a glance at another Tasmanian midfielder destined for the top 10.
Ryley Sanders is a big-bodied workhorse in midfield who dominated his under-18 year with his combination of inside grunt and outside skill.
(Getty Images)

The Larke Medallist teamed up with Colby McKercher to lead the Allies to victory in the state champs and enjoyed a fantastic season with the Sandringham Dragons. He proved a commanding presence in midfield, a real leader of both sides, and quickly became a favourite among draft watchers.

It's a stretch to say he plays like him, but with the blonde hair and pulled-up socks he does genuinely look like Jason Horne-Francis when he plays. He doesn't have the explosive athleticism of Horne-Francis, but he does move a bit like him and makes up for that lack of top-level pace with a fantastic work ethic.
(Getty Images)
He's a little more one-paced than someone like McKercher, but he's quick enough. And when he's frame fills out further he could well be a force for any AFL midfield.
North Melbourne are big fans and tried to get the AFL to let them have priority access to him via their NGA, but Sanders is available to all and sundry on the open market.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west. "To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this. "I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9." Cousins. Naitanui. Reid? If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Harley Reid: West Coast's number 9?

children.content: (Getty Images)
The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west.
"To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this.
"I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9."
Cousins. Naitanui. Reid?
If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yesterday, Adrian Dodoro flagged that Essendon would be submitting paperwork for St Kilda's Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours. That means we should be expecting some movement today. From all reports, if the offer triggers band two compensation — which would mean St Kilda get an end-of-first-round pick — the Saints would not match. But anything less than that and they would try to get the Bombers to the trade table. At that point, there's a pretty good chance Gresham stays put. So it all hangs on the Essendon offer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will we get some Jade Gresham news today?

children.content: (Getty Images)
Yesterday, Adrian Dodoro flagged that Essendon would be submitting paperwork for St Kilda's Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours. That means we should be expecting some movement today.

From all reports, if the offer triggers band two compensation — which would mean St Kilda get an end-of-first-round pick — the Saints would not match. But anything less than that and they would try to get the Bombers to the trade table.
At that point, there's a pretty good chance Gresham stays put. So it all hangs on the Essendon offer.

image.altText: A man wearing a high vis vest with his face blurred points toward a man while another man watches on

items.synopsis: Police charge a 23-year-old man with intimidation after four teens were allegedly threatened for displaying an Israeli flag across their car in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: Sydney man charged after allegedly threatening teens who displayed Israeli flag on car

image.altText: A family of four smiling

items.synopsis: Hundreds of caravans and camper trailers crash every year. Police in Queensland say about 90 per cent of recreational vehicles weigh too much, creating a safety hazard and potentially voiding the owners' insurance.

title.children: Rob loves camping in his caravan, but a check found something simple putting his family's safety at risk

image.altText: Two men put ballot papers into a box.

items.synopsis: The crisis in Israel is unlikely to directly shift votes one way or another in the Australian Voice referendum, but it does make it harder for the Yes campaign to be heard at precisely the time it needs to be, writes David Speers.

title.children: With days left for the Voice campaign, it just got harder for Yes and Albanese to break through

image.altText: Seb and Ella McCorry

items.synopsis: Sebastian and Ella McCorry, 18, are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts.

title.children: These twin high-schoolers say misinformation on the Voice is rampant among teens, so they're trying to fix that

image.altText: Alyssa Healy bats to the leg side against West Indies in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The West Indies battled their way to just 83 in the first one-day international in Brisbane, so they will be hoping for a big improvement against Australia at Junction Oval. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

title.children: ODI live: Shortened clash between Australia and West Indies finally underway after rain delay

image.altText: Man sits at a piano and plays

items.synopsis: In the era of reboots, it's time for Frasier to have his moment, here's what we thought.

title.children: Frasier is back — here's what you need to know about the reboot
